pli-tv-kd16:1.1.1.pli: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
pli-tv-kd16:1.1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrel sanctuary.

pli-tv-kd16:1.1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavatā bhikkhūnaṃ senāsanaṃ apaññattaṃ hoti.
pli-tv-kd16:1.1.2.eng: At this time the Buddha had not yet allowed dwellings.
pli-tv-kd16:1.1.2.comm: In the broadest sense senāsana means “resting place”, which includes everything from the foot of a tree to furniture and huts. The current chapter focuses on furniture and dwellings. Here, however, the meaning is huts or dwellings. For a further discussion of senāsana, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd16:1.1.3.pli: Te ca bhikkhū tahaṃ tahaṃ viharanti—
pli-tv-kd16:1.1.3.eng: As a result, the monks stayed here and there:

pli-tv-kd16:1.1.4.pli: araññe, rukkhamūle, pabbate, kandarāyaṃ, giriguhāyaṃ, susāne, vanapatthe, ajjhokāse, palālapuñje.
pli-tv-kd16:1.1.4.eng: in the wilderness, at the foot of a tree, on a hill, in a gorge, in a hillside cave, in a charnel ground, in the forest, in the open, on a heap of straw.

pli-tv-kd16:1.1.5.eng: Early in the morning, they would emerge from those places.

pli-tv-kd16:1.1.6.pli: araññā rukkhamūlā pabbatā kandarā giriguhā susānā vanapatthā ajjhokāsā palālapuñjā, pāsādikena abhikkantena paṭikkantena, ālokitena vilokitena, samiñjitena pasāritena, okkhittacakkhū, iriyāpathasampannā.
pli-tv-kd16:1.1.6.eng: They were pleasing in their conduct: in going out and coming back, in looking ahead and looking aside, in bending and stretching their arms. Their eyes were lowered, and they were perfect in deportment.

pli-tv-kd16:1.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rājagahako seṭṭhī kālasseva uyyānaṃ agamāsi.
pli-tv-kd16:1.2.1.eng: One morning a wealthy merchant of Rājagaha was going to a park

pli-tv-kd16:1.2.2.pli: Addasā kho rājagahako seṭṭhī te bhikkhū kālasseva tato tato upanikkhamante—

pli-tv-kd16:1.2.3.pli: araññā rukkhamūlā pabbatā kandarā giriguhā susānā vanapatthā ajjhokāsā palālapuñjā, pāsādikena abhikkantena paṭikkantena, ālokitena vilokitena, samiñjitena pasāritena, okkhittacakkhū, iriyāpathasampanne.

pli-tv-kd16:1.2.5.pli: Atha kho rājagahako seṭṭhī yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā te bhikkhū etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd16:1.2.6.pli: “sacāhaṃ, bhante, vihāre kārāpeyyaṃ, vaseyyātha me vihāresū”ti?
pli-tv-kd16:1.2.6.eng: “If I build dwellings, sirs, would you stay in them?”

pli-tv-kd16:1.2.8.pli: “Tena hi, bhante, bhagavantaṃ paṭipucchitvā mama āroceyyāthā”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:1.2.8.eng: “Well then, please ask the Buddha and let me know his response.”

pli-tv-kd16:1.2.10.pli: kho te bhikkhū rājagahakassa seṭṭhissa paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
pli-tv-kd16:1.2.10.eng: Those monks then went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down,

pli-tv-kd16:1.2.11.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ—

pli-tv-kd16:1.2.12.eng: “Sir, a wealthy merchant in Rājagaha wants to build dwellings.

pli-tv-kd16:1.2.13.pli: Kathaṃ nu kho, bhante, amhehi paṭipajjitabban”ti?

pli-tv-kd16:1.2.14.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etasmiṃ nidāne etasmiṃ pakaraṇe dhammiṃ kathaṃ katvā bhikkhū āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd16:1.2.14.eng: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd16:1.2.15.comm: Sp-ṭ 4.294: Pañca leṇānīti pañca līyanaṭṭhānāni. Nilīyanti ettha bhikkhūti leṇāni, “The five leṇas: the five places for resting. Leṇas are where monks hide away.”

pli-tv-kd16:1.2.16.eng: dwellings, three kinds of stilt houses, and caves.”
pli-tv-kd16:1.2.16.comm: For an explanation of the renderings “stilt house” and “cave” for pāsāda and guhā respectively, see Appendix of Technical Terms. Apart from vihāra, “dwellings”, and guhā, “caves”, the Pali mentions three kinds of buildings, the aḍḍhayoga, the pāsāda, and the hammiya, all of which, according to the commentaries, are different kinds of pāsāda, “stilt houses”. Rather than try to differentiate between these buildings, which is unlikely to be useful from a practical perspective, I have instead grouped them together as “stilt houses”. Here is what the commentaries have to say. Sp 4.294: Aḍḍhayogoti supaṇṇavaṅkagehaṁ, “An aḍḍhayoga is a house bent like a supaṇṇa.” Sp-ṭ 4.294 clarifies: Supaṇṇavaṅkagehanti garuḷapakkhasaṇṭhānena katagehaṁ, “Supaṇṇavaṅkageha: a house made in the shape of the wings of a garuḷa.” A garuḷa, better known in its Sanskrit form garuḍa, is a mythological bird. Sp 4.294 continues: Pāsādoti dīghapāsādo. Hammiyanti upariākāsatale patiṭṭhitakūṭāgāro pāsādoyeva, “A pāsāda is a long stilt house. A hammiya is just a pāsāda that has an upper room on top of its flat roof.” At Sp-ṭ 3.74, however, we find slightly different explanations. It seems clear, however, that all three are stilt houses and that they are distinguished according to their shape and the kind of roof they possess.

pli-tv-kd16:1.3.1.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū yena rājagahako seṭṭhī tenupasaṅkamiṃsu, upasaṅkamitvā rājagahakaṃ seṭṭhiṃ etadavocuṃ—
pli-tv-kd16:1.3.1.eng: The monks went to that merchant and said,

pli-tv-kd16:1.3.3.eng: Please do as you think appropriate.”

pli-tv-kd16:1.3.4.pli: Atha kho rājagahako seṭṭhī ekāheneva saṭṭhivihāre patiṭṭhāpesi.
pli-tv-kd16:1.3.4.eng: Then, on a single day, that merchant built sixty dwellings.

pli-tv-kd16:1.3.5.pli: Atha kho rājagahako seṭṭhī te saṭṭhivihāre pariyosāpetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd16:1.3.5.eng: When the dwellings were finished, he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down,

pli-tv-kd16:1.3.6.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājagahako seṭṭhī bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd16:1.3.7.pli: “adhivāsetu me, bhante, bhagavā svātanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:1.3.7.eng: “Sir, please accept tomorrow’s meal from me together with the Sangha of monks.”

pli-tv-kd16:1.3.8.eng: The Buddha consented by remaining silent.

pli-tv-kd16:1.3.9.pli: Atha kho rājagahako seṭṭhī bhagavato adhivāsanaṃ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd16:1.3.9.eng: Knowing that the Buddha had consented, he got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left.

pli-tv-kd16:1.4.1.pli: Atha kho rājagahako seṭṭhī tassā rattiyā accayena paṇītaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ paṭiyādāpetvā bhagavato kālaṃ ārocāpesi—
pli-tv-kd16:1.4.1.eng: The next morning he had various kinds of fine foods prepared and then had the Buddha informed

pli-tv-kd16:1.4.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena rājagahakassa seṭṭhissa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena.
pli-tv-kd16:1.4.3.eng: The Buddha robe up, took his bowl and robe, and went to the house of that merchant where he sat down on the prepared seat together with the Sangha of monks.

pli-tv-kd16:1.4.4.pli: Atha kho rājagahako seṭṭhī buddhappamukhaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappetvā sampavāretvā, bhagavantaṃ bhuttāviṃ onītapattapāṇiṃ, ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd16:1.4.4.eng: That merchant personally served various kinds of fine foods to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha. When the Buddha had finished his meal and had washed his hands and bowl, the merchant sat down to one side

pli-tv-kd16:1.4.5.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājagahako seṭṭhī bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd16:1.4.6.pli: “ete me, bhante, saṭṭhivihārā puññatthikena saggatthikena kārāpitā.
pli-tv-kd16:1.4.6.eng: “Sir, I’ve had these sixty dwellings built in order to make merit and for the purpose of going to heaven.

pli-tv-kd16:1.4.8.pli: “Tena hi tvaṃ, gahapati, te saṭṭhivihāre āgatānāgatassa cātuddisassa saṅghassa patiṭṭhāpehī”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:1.4.8.eng: “Well then, give those sixty dwellings to the Sangha as a whole, both present and future.”

pli-tv-kd16:1.4.9.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho rājagahako seṭṭhī bhagavato paṭissutvā te saṭṭhivihāre āgatānāgatassa cātuddisassa saṅghassa patiṭṭhāpesi.
pli-tv-kd16:1.4.9.eng: Saying, “Yes, sir,” he did just that.

pli-tv-kd16:1.5.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā rājagahakaṃ seṭṭhiṃ imāhi gāthāhi anumodi—
pli-tv-kd16:1.5.1.eng: The Buddha then expressed his appreciation to the merchant with these verses:

pli-tv-kd16:1.5.6.eng: They keep away the wind and burning sun,

pli-tv-kd16:1.5.8.eng: Their purpose is to shelter and for happiness,

pli-tv-kd16:1.5.9.eng: To attain absorption and to see clearly.

pli-tv-kd16:1.5.11.eng: Is praised as the best by the Buddha.

pli-tv-kd16:1.5.15.eng: And have the learned stay there.

pli-tv-kd16:1.5.20.eng: They will give him the Teaching

pli-tv-kd16:1.5.22.eng: And understanding this Teaching in this life,

pli-tv-kd16:1.5.23.eng: He attains extinguishment, free of corruptions.”

pli-tv-kd16:1.5.24.pli: Atha kho bhagavā rājagahakaṃ seṭṭhiṃ imāhi gāthāhi anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd16:1.5.24.eng: The Buddha then got up from his seat and left.

pli-tv-kd16:2.1.1.eng: Hearing that the Buddha had allowed dwellings,

pli-tv-kd16:2.1.2.pli: “bhagavatā kira vihārā anuññātā”ti sakkaccaṃ vihāre kārāpenti.
pli-tv-kd16:2.1.2.eng: people had dwellings built with care.

pli-tv-kd16:2.1.3.eng: But because the dwellings did not have doors,

pli-tv-kd16:2.1.4.eng: snakes, scorpions, and centipedes came inside.

pli-tv-kd16:2.1.7.pli: Bhittichiddaṃ karitvā valliyāpi rajjuyāpi kavāṭaṃ bandhanti.
pli-tv-kd16:2.1.7.eng: They made a hole in the wall and bound the doors with creepers and ropes.

pli-tv-kd16:2.1.8.eng: Rats and termites ate the creepers and ropes,

pli-tv-kd16:2.1.11.eng: “I allow door frames, and lower and upper hinges.”
pli-tv-kd16:2.1.11.comm: “Door frame” renders piṭṭhasaṅghāṭa. The precise meaning of the two words that make up this compound is never clarified in the Pali texts, but it seems clear enough that the compound as a whole refers to the entire door frame, for instance when it is used to define the dvārakosa at Bu Pc 19:2.1.7. Vmv 1.349: Piṭṭhasaṅghāṭo nāma dvārabāhasaṅkhāto caturassadārusaṅghāṭo, yattha sauttarapāsaṁ kavāṭaṁ apassāya dvāraṁ pidahanti, “Piṭṭhasaṅghāṭo: a rectangular binding together of wood, called a doorcase, where the door with its hinges are supported and shut the doorway.” “Lower and upper hinges” renders udukkhalika and uttarapāsaka, respectively. Sp 1.77: … yena kenaci kavāṭaṁ katvā heṭṭhā udukkhale upari uttarapāsake ca pavesetvā kataṁ parivattakadvārameva saṁvaritabbaṁ … atha dvārassa udukkhalaṁ vā uttarapāsako vā bhinno vā hoti aṭṭhapito vā, saṁvarituṁ na sakkoti, “Having made a door by whatever (material), having entered it into the udukkhala below and into the uttarapāsaka above, it is made a revolving door to be closed … but when the udukkhala or the uttarapāsaka is broken or not mounted, then one cannot close the door.” From this it seems that the udukkhala and uttarapāsaka, together with the two corresponding “projecting pivots” on the door, are the functional equivalents of hinges. Udukkhalika and udukkhala refer to the same thing, the former being used in the canonical text, whereas the latter is found in the summary verses. For further details see CPD, sv. uttarapāsaka.

pli-tv-kd16:2.1.12.eng: The doors did not fit the door frames.
pli-tv-kd16:2.1.12.comm: Elsewhere we find the closely related expression phusitaggaḷa, “with a touching door”, to describe a well-built house, e.g. at MN 12:41.4. The same description says that the house is nivāta, “free from drafts”. MN-a 1.154 comments: Phusitaggaḷanti dvārabāhāhi saddhiṁ supihitakavāṭaṁ, “With a touching door: the door-panel closes well with the door frame.” The point seems to be that the door is closed all the way so that it touches the door frame.

pli-tv-kd16:2.1.14.eng: “I allow a hole in the door and a rope for pulling.”
pli-tv-kd16:2.1.14.comm: “A hole in the door (for pulling)” and “a rope for pulling” render āviñchanachidda and āviñchanarajju respectively. Vmv 4.296: Āviñchanachiddanti yattha aṅguliṁ vā rajjusaṅkhalikādiṁ vā pavesetvā kavāṭaṁ ākaḍḍhantā dvārabāhaṁ phusāpenti, “Āviñchanachidda: where, having entered the finger or a rope or a chain, etc., they pull the door and make it touch the door post.” Sp 4.296: Āviñchanarajjunti kavāṭeyeva chiddaṁ katvā tattha pavesetvā yena rajjukena kaḍḍhantā dvāraṁ phusāpenti, “Having made a hole in the door, having entered (the rope) there, the rope with which they close and make the door touch (the post).”

pli-tv-kd16:2.1.15.eng: The doors did not stay closed.
pli-tv-kd16:2.1.15.comm: The commentaries are silent. Under the entry thaketi, DOP says: “covers, covers up; closes”. The context, however, suggests that this concerns more than merely closing the door, which is already effected by the hole and the rope mentioned just above. That more than closing is meant is also apparent from the fact that the remedy is to allow the use of bolts.

pli-tv-kd16:2.1.17.eng: “I allow door jambs, bolt sockets, bolts, and latches.”
pli-tv-kd16:2.1.17.comm: “Door jamb” renders aggaḷavaṭṭi. Sp 4.260: Aggaḷavaṭṭi nāma dvārabāhāya samappamāṇoyeva aggaḷatthambho vuccati, yattha tīṇi cattāri chiddāni katvā sūciyo denti, “Aggaḷavaṭṭi: it is called a door post, which is the same length as the door frame. It is where three or four holes are made for inserting bolts.” Whenever the Canonical text lists the parts of a door and door frame, the aggaḷavaṭṭi always has the same position, being grouped together with the parts for the locking mechanism, such as latches and bolts. Given the commentarial explanation, it is natural to think that it was a special post added to the door frame, or perhaps replacing the door frame, for the purpose of receiving bolts. “Bolt socket” renders kapisīsaka. Sp 4.260: Kapisīsakaṁ nāma dvārabāhaṁ vijjhitvā tattha pavesito aggaḷapāsako vuccati, “The bolt-receiving socket which is inserted after piercing the door post is called a kapisīsaka.” “Bolt” renders sūcika. Sp 4.260: Sūcikāti tattha majjhe chiddaṁ katvā pavesitā, “It is entered, having made a hole in the middle there.” “Latch” renders ghaṭika. Sp-ṭ 4.255: Ghaṭikanti upari yojitaṁ aggaḷaṁ, “Ghaṭika: it connected the door at the top.” From the origin story to Bu Ss 2:1.1.11 it seems that the ghaṭika was a device that could be opened with a key: Avāpuraṇaṁ ādāya ghaṭikaṁ ugghāṭetvā kavāṭaṁ paṇāmetvā vihāraṁ pāvisi, “(Udāyī) took the key, lifted the latch, opened the door, and entered the dwelling.” It follows from this that the ghaṭika is unlikely to be a bolt, but probably a kind of bar, like a latch, that would require lifting for the door to open. The lifting would be done with tāḷa, a key-like device, for which see below. For a discussion of the aggaḷa as “door”, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd16:2.1.18.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū na sakkonti kavāṭaṃ apāpurituṃ.
pli-tv-kd16:2.1.18.eng: The monks were unable to open the doors.
pli-tv-kd16:2.1.18.comm: It is not clear why this would be so. Perhaps the latch would fasten automatically as the door was closed, but it would then be impossible to get back inside.

pli-tv-kd16:2.1.22.eng: metal keys, wooden keys, and keys made of horn.”

pli-tv-kd16:2.1.23.pli: Yehi te ugghāṭetvā pavisanti, vihārā aguttā honti.
pli-tv-kd16:2.1.23.eng: They lifted the latches with the keys and entered, but the dwellings were unprotected.
pli-tv-kd16:2.1.23.comm: Again, it is not clear to me why this would be the case.

pli-tv-kd16:2.1.25.comm: A yantaka seems to be any implement that is used as a bolt, whereas a sūcika is a bolt proper. Sp 4.296: Yantakaṁ sūcikanti ettha yaṁ yaṁ jānāti taṁ taṁ yantakaṁ, tassa vivaraṇasūcikañca kātuṁ vaṭṭati, “Here, whatever he finds, that is a yantaka; to make a bolt of it for opening is allowed.” It is not clear why bolts, sūcika, are mentioned both here and above. It is possible that the text has evolved over time.

pli-tv-kd16:2.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena vihārā tiṇacchadanā honti;
pli-tv-kd16:2.2.1.eng: At that time the dwellings had roofs of straw.

pli-tv-kd16:2.2.2.eng: When the weather was cold, they were cold, and when the weather was hot, they were hot.

pli-tv-kd16:2.2.4.eng: “I allow you to firm up the structure and then to plaster it inside and outside.”
pli-tv-kd16:2.2.4.comm: “Firm up the structure” renders ogumphetvā. Sp 4.257: Ogumphetvā ullittāvalittaṁ kātunti chadanaṁ odhunitvā ghanadaṇḍakaṁ katvā anto ceva bahi ca mattikāya limpitunti attho, “Ogumphetvā ullittāvalittaṁ kātuṁ: having shook out the roof cover and added rods to firm up (the structure), to smear with clay inside and outside—this is the meaning.” At Kd 5:11.1.5 the same verb, in the form ogumphiyanti, is used to show how dwellings are “held together” by straps of leather. This makes it certain that ogumphetvā in the present context must refer to “firming up” rather than “shaking out”.

pli-tv-kd16:2.2.5.pli: Tena kho pana samayena vihārā avātapānakā honti acakkhussā duggandhā.
pli-tv-kd16:2.2.5.eng: At that time the dwellings did not have windows. It was hard to see and the dwellings were smelly.
pli-tv-kd16:2.2.5.comm: The usual meaning of acakkhussa is “bad for the eyes”. According to SED, however, it can also mean “blind”; sv. acakshushka.

pli-tv-kd16:2.2.8.eng: railing windows, lattice windows, and windows with bars.”
pli-tv-kd16:2.2.8.comm: “Railing windows” renders vedikāvātapāna. Sp 4.296: Vedikāvātapānaṁ nāma cetiye vedikāsadisaṁ, “(A window) like the railing on a shrine is called vedikāvātapāna.” “Windows with bars” renders salākavātapāna. Sp 4.296: Salākavātapānaṁ nāma thambhakavātapānaṁ, “Windows with rods are called salākavātapāna.”

pli-tv-kd16:2.2.9.eng: Squirrels and bats entered the dwellings through the gaps in the windows.

pli-tv-kd16:2.2.11.comm: Sp 4.296: Cakkalikanti ettha “coḷakapādapuñchanaṁ bandhituṁ anujānāmī”ti attho, “Cakkalika: the meaning is: ‘I allow to bind a foot-wiping cloth there.’”

pli-tv-kd16:2.2.12.eng: The squirrels and bats entered in the gaps around the cloth cover.

pli-tv-kd16:2.2.14.comm: I am not able to make a distinction between vātapānakavāṭaka and vātapānabhisika that is meaningful in English. Vātapānakavāṭaka, literally, means “a small door for the windows”. The vātapānabhisika is described at Sp 4.296: Vātapānabhisīti vātapānappamāṇena bhisiṁ katvā bandhituṁ anujānāmīti attho, “Vātapānabhisi: the meaning is: ‘I allow, having made a small mattress the size of the window, to bind it on.’”

pli-tv-kd16:2.3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū chamāyaṃ sayanti.
pli-tv-kd16:2.3.1.eng: At that time the monks lay down on the ground.

pli-tv-kd16:2.3.2.eng: They became dirty, as did their robes.

pli-tv-kd16:2.3.5.eng: The grass was eaten by rats and termites.

pli-tv-kd16:2.3.7.comm: For further discussion of the Pali terminology behind this and the next item, see Appendix of Furniture.

pli-tv-kd16:2.3.8.eng: The benches were painful to lie on.

pli-tv-kd16:2.3.11.0.eng: 2. The allowance for beds and benches

pli-tv-kd16:2.3.11.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena saṅghassa sosāniko masārako mañco uppanno hoti.
pli-tv-kd16:2.3.11.1.eng: Soon afterwards the Sangha was offered various kinds of beds with legs and frames from a charnel ground.
pli-tv-kd16:2.3.11.1.comm: Vin-vn-ṭ 663: Sosānikanti susāne chaḍḍitaṁ, “Sosānika means what is discarded on a charnel ground.” The text gives two different kinds of beds (and benches just below) called masāraka and bundikābaddha. The only difference between the two seems to be how the rails are fastened to the legs. From this it seems reasonable to conclude that all beds with legs and a frame are allowable, as long as they adhere to the other standards of the Vinaya, such as Bu Pc 87:1.11.1. Thus my decision to group these beds and benches together as “various kinds of beds/benches”. For further discussion, see Appendix of Furniture.

pli-tv-kd16:2.3.13.eng: “I allow the various kinds of beds with legs and frames.”

pli-tv-kd16:2.3.14.eng: The Sangha was offered various kinds of benches with legs and frames.

pli-tv-kd16:2.3.16.eng: “I allow the various kinds of benches with legs and frames.”

pli-tv-kd16:2.3.17.pli: Tena kho pana samayena saṅghassa sosāniko bundikābaddho mañco uppanno hoti.

pli-tv-kd16:2.3.23.pli: Tena kho pana samayena saṅghassa sosāniko kuḷīrapādako mañco uppanno hoti.
pli-tv-kd16:2.3.23.eng: The Sangha was offered a bed with crooked legs from a charnel ground.

pli-tv-kd16:2.3.25.comm: For a further discussion of this and the various items below, see Appendix of Furniture.

pli-tv-kd16:2.3.26.eng: The Sangha was offered a bench with crooked legs.

pli-tv-kd16:2.3.29.pli: Tena kho pana samayena saṅghassa sosāniko āhaccapādako mañco uppanno hoti.
pli-tv-kd16:2.3.29.eng: The Sangha was offered a bed with detachable legs from a charnel ground.

pli-tv-kd16:2.3.32.eng: The Sangha was offered a bench with detachable legs.

pli-tv-kd16:2.4.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena saṅghassa āsandiko uppanno hoti.
pli-tv-kd16:2.4.1.eng: The Sangha was offered a square bench.

pli-tv-kd16:2.4.4.eng: The Sangha was offered a tall square bench.

pli-tv-kd16:2.4.7.eng: The Sangha was offered a sofa.

pli-tv-kd16:2.4.10.eng: The Sangha was offered a high sofa.

pli-tv-kd16:2.4.13.eng: The Sangha was offered a cane bench.

pli-tv-kd16:2.4.16.eng: The Sangha was offered a small bench bound with pieces of cloth.

pli-tv-kd16:2.4.18.eng: “I allow small benches bound with pieces of cloth.”

pli-tv-kd16:2.4.19.eng: The Sangha was offered a bench with ram-like legs.

pli-tv-kd16:2.4.22.eng: The Sangha was offered a bench with many legs.

pli-tv-kd16:2.4.25.eng: The Sangha was offered a plank as a bench.

pli-tv-kd16:2.4.28.eng: The Sangha was offered a stool.

pli-tv-kd16:2.4.31.eng: The Sangha was offered a bench made of straw.

pli-tv-kd16:2.5.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū ucce mañce sayanti.
pli-tv-kd16:2.5.1.eng: At that time the monks from the group of six slept on high beds.

pli-tv-kd16:2.5.2.pli: Manussā vihāracārikaṃ āhiṇḍantā passitvā ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-kd16:2.5.2.eng: When people walking about the dwellings saw this, they complained and criticized them,

pli-tv-kd16:2.5.3.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd16:2.5.6.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd16:2.5.7.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu nīce mañce sayanto ahinā daṭṭho hoti.
pli-tv-kd16:2.5.7.eng: Soon afterwards a monk was bitten by a snake while sleeping on a low bed.

pli-tv-kd16:2.5.9.comm: These were not legs but a loose kind of prop used to keep the bed off the ground, see Kd 1:25.15.3 and Kd 1:25.16.2.

pli-tv-kd16:2.5.10.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū ucce mañcapaṭipādake dhārenti, saha mañcapaṭipādakehi pavedhenti.
pli-tv-kd16:2.5.10.eng: The monks from the group of six used high bed supports and then made the beds shake.

pli-tv-kd16:2.5.11.pli: Manussā vihāracārikaṃ āhiṇḍantā passitvā ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-kd16:2.5.11.eng: When people walking about the dwellings saw this, they complained and criticized them,

pli-tv-kd16:2.5.12.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd16:2.5.15.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd16:2.5.16.eng: I allow bed supports that are at the most eight standard fingerbreadths long.”
pli-tv-kd16:2.5.16.comm: I take aṭṭhaṅgulaparama to be equivalent to the maximum height allowed under Bu Pc 87:1.11.1, where the aṅgula is specified as the sugataṅgula, “the standard fingerbreadth”. See sugata in Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd16:2.6.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena saṅghassa suttaṃ uppannaṃ hoti.

pli-tv-kd16:2.6.3.eng: “I allow you to wrap the beds with string.”

pli-tv-kd16:2.6.4.eng: The limbs of the bed took up a lot of string.

pli-tv-kd16:2.6.6.eng: “I allow you to perforate the limbs and wrap with a cross weaving.”
pli-tv-kd16:2.6.6.comm: The meaning of this is not clear. The commentaries are silent.

pli-tv-kd16:2.6.7.eng: The Sangha was offered a cloth.

pli-tv-kd16:2.6.9.eng: “I allow you to make a mat underlay.”
pli-tv-kd16:2.6.9.comm: For further discussion of the cimilika, see Appendix of Furniture.

pli-tv-kd16:2.6.10.eng: The Sangha was offered a cotton-down quilt.

pli-tv-kd16:2.6.12.eng: “I allow you to remove the cotton down and make pillows.

pli-tv-kd16:2.6.13.eng: There are three kinds of cotton down:

pli-tv-kd16:2.6.14.eng: cotton down from trees, cotton down from creepers, and cotton down from grass.”

pli-tv-kd16:2.6.15.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū addhakāyikāni bibbohanāni dhārenti.
pli-tv-kd16:2.6.15.eng: The monks from the group of six used pillows that were half the size of the body.

pli-tv-kd16:2.6.16.pli: Manussā vihāracārikaṃ āhiṇḍantā passitvā ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-kd16:2.6.16.eng: When people walking about the dwellings saw this, they complained and criticized them,

pli-tv-kd16:2.6.17.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd16:2.6.19.eng: “You shouldn’t use pillows that are half the size of the body.

pli-tv-kd16:2.6.20.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd16:2.6.21.eng: I allow you to make pillows the size of the head.”

pli-tv-kd16:2.7.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rājagahe giraggasamajjo hoti.
pli-tv-kd16:2.7.1.eng: On one occasion in Rājagaha there was a hilltop fair.

pli-tv-kd16:2.7.2.eng: People prepared mattresses for the government officials:
pli-tv-kd16:2.7.2.comm: “Government official” renders mahāmattā. Sp 1.92, commenting on Bu Pj 2, says: Mahāmattāti ṭhānantarappattā mahāamaccā; tepi tattha tattha gāme vā nigame vā nisīditvā rājakiccaṁ karonti, “Mahāmattā means an important worker, who has attained a position; those who sit down in this or that village or town, and do the work of the king.” Mahāmatta is often translated as “minister” or even “great minister”, but the relatively small scale of ancient Indian society suggests a more humble translation.

pli-tv-kd16:2.7.3.eng: mattresses stuffed with wool, cloth, bark, grass, or leaves.

pli-tv-kd16:2.7.4.pli: Te vītivatte samajje chaviṃ uppāṭetvā haranti.
pli-tv-kd16:2.7.4.eng: When the fair was over, they removed the covers and took them away.

pli-tv-kd16:2.7.5.pli: Addasāsuṃ kho bhikkhū samajjaṭṭhāne bahuṃ uṇṇampi coḷakampi vākampi tiṇampi paṇṇampi chaṭṭitaṃ.
pli-tv-kd16:2.7.5.eng: The monks saw a large quantity of wool, cloth, bark, grass, and leaves abandoned on the ground.

pli-tv-kd16:2.7.8.eng: mattresses stuffed with wool, cloth, bark, grass, or leaves.”

pli-tv-kd16:2.7.9.pli: Tena kho pana samayena saṅghassa senāsanaparikkhārikaṃ dussaṃ uppannaṃ hoti.
pli-tv-kd16:2.7.9.eng: The Sangha was offered furniture cloth.

pli-tv-kd16:2.7.11.eng: “I allow you to cover the mattresses.”

pli-tv-kd16:2.7.12.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū mañcabhisiṃ pīṭhe santharanti, pīṭhabhisiṃ mañce santharanti.
pli-tv-kd16:2.7.12.eng: The monks laid a bed mattress on a bench and a bench mattress on a bed.

pli-tv-kd16:2.7.15.eng: “I allow upholstered beds and upholstered benches.”

pli-tv-kd16:2.7.16.eng: They laid out mattresses without underlay. They sank down.
pli-tv-kd16:2.7.16.comm: Sp 4.297: Ullokaṁ akaritvāti heṭṭhā cimilikaṁ adatvā, “Ullokaṁ akaritvā: not having applied an underlay beneath.”

pli-tv-kd16:2.7.17.pli: “anujānāmi, bhikkhave, ullokaṃ karitvā santharitvā bhisiṃ onandhitun”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:2.7.17.eng: “I allow you to arrange an underlay, then to lay down a mattress, and then to cover it.”

pli-tv-kd16:2.7.18.eng: The covers were removed and taken away.

pli-tv-kd16:2.7.19.comm: Sp 4.297: Phositunti rajanena vā haliddiyā vā upari phusitāni dātuṁ, “To sprinkle means to apply spots of dye or turmeric on top.” Sp-ṭ 4.297: Phusitāni dātunti saññākaraṇatthaṁ bindūni dātuṁ, “To apply spots means to apply marks for the purpose of recognition.”

pli-tv-kd16:2.7.21.eng: “I allow you to make multi-colored lines.”
pli-tv-kd16:2.7.21.comm: Sp 4.297: “Bhattikammanti bhisicchaviyā upari bhattikammaṁ, “Bhattikamma means bhattikamma on top of the mattress covering.” Vmv 4.297: “Bhittikammanti nānāvaṇṇehi vibhittirājikaraṇaṁ”, “Bhittikamma means making separate lines by means of many colors.” According to SED, the Sanskrit bhakti can mean “distribution, partition, separation”, “division by streaks or lines”, or “a streak, line, variegated decoration”. Based on this, it seems possible that bhatti refers to multi-colored lines drawn on the cloth.

pli-tv-kd16:2.7.23.eng: “I allow you to make multi-colored lines by hand.”
pli-tv-kd16:2.7.23.comm: It is not clear what the difference is between hatthabhattikamma and hatthabhatti, the latter being found in the next rule. Hatthabhattikamma is not mentioned in the commentaries, nor is it found in the PTS version of the Canon. It may be that this word has been accidentally added to MS.

pli-tv-kd16:2.7.25.comm: Sp 4.297: “Hatthabhattinti pañcaṅgulibhattiṁ, “Hatthabhatti means bhatti with the five fingers.” Commenting on the word hatthakamma, “hand-work”, Vmv 4.297 says: “Hatthakammanti hatthena yaṁ kiñci saññākaraṇaṁ”, “Hatthakamma means whatever mark is made by hand.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.1.0.eng: 3. The allowance for the color white, etc.

pli-tv-kd16:3.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena titthiyānaṃ seyyāyo setavaṇṇā honti, kāḷavaṇṇakatā bhūmi, gerukaparikammakatā bhitti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.1.1.eng: At that time the monastics of other religions had white beds, black floors, and red ocher walls.

pli-tv-kd16:3.1.2.eng: Many people went to see their beds.

pli-tv-kd16:3.1.4.eng: “I allow the colors white, black, and red ocher in the dwellings.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.1.5.pli: Tena kho pana samayena pharusāya bhittiyā setavaṇṇo na nipatati.
pli-tv-kd16:3.1.5.eng: The white color did not adhere to the rough walls.
pli-tv-kd16:3.1.5.comm: Vmv 4.298: Pāḷiyaṁ na nipatatīti na allīyati, “In the Canonical text, na nipatati means not sticking.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.1.7.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, thusapiṇḍaṃ datvā pāṇikāya paṭibāhetvā setavaṇṇaṃ nipātetun”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.1.7.eng: “I allow you to apply balls of husk, smooth with a trowel, and then apply the white color.”
pli-tv-kd16:3.1.7.comm: Sp-ṭ 4.298: Paṭibāhetvāti maṭṭhaṁ katvā, “Paṭibāhetva means having polished.” Vmv 4.298: Paṭibāhetvāti ghaṁsitvā, “Paṭibāhetva means having rubbed.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.1.8.eng: The white color still did not adhere.
pli-tv-kd16:3.1.8.comm: Sp-ṭ 4.298: Na nibandhatīti anibandhanīyo, na allīyatīti attho, “Anibandhanīyo: ʻIt does not bind’; the meaning is ʻit does not stick’.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.1.9.pli: “anujānāmi, bhikkhave, saṇhamattikaṃ datvā pāṇikāya paṭibāhetvā setavaṇṇaṃ nipātetun”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.1.9.eng: “I allow you to apply soft clay, smooth with a trowel, and then apply the white color.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.1.10.eng: The white color still did not adhere.

pli-tv-kd16:3.1.11.comm: “Sap” renders ikkāsa. Sp 4.298: Ikkāsanti rukkhaniyyāsaṁ vā silesaṁ vā, “Ikkāsa means exudation from a tree or gum.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.1.12.pli: Tena kho pana samayena pharusāya bhittiyā gerukā na nipatati.
pli-tv-kd16:3.1.12.eng: The red ocher did not adhere to the rough walls.

pli-tv-kd16:3.1.14.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, thusapiṇḍaṃ datvā pāṇikāya paṭibāhetvā gerukaṃ nipātetun”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.1.14.eng: “I allow you to apply balls of husk, smooth with a trowel, and then apply the red ocher.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.1.15.eng: The red ocher still did not adhere.

pli-tv-kd16:3.1.16.pli: “anujānāmi, bhikkhave, kuṇḍakamattikaṃ datvā pāṇikāya paṭibāhetvā gerukaṃ nipātetun”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.1.16.eng: “I allow you to apply clay mixed with bran, smooth with a trowel, and then apply the red ocher.”
pli-tv-kd16:3.1.16.comm: Sp 4.298: Kuṇḍakamattikanti kuṇḍakamissakamattikaṁ, “Kuṇḍakamattika means clay mixed with bran.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.1.17.eng: The red ocher still did not adhere.

pli-tv-kd16:3.1.20.eng: “I allow you to wipe it off with a cloth.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.1.21.pli: Tena kho pana samayena pharusāya bhūmiyā kāḷavaṇṇo na nipatati.
pli-tv-kd16:3.1.21.eng: The black color did not adhere to the rough floors.

pli-tv-kd16:3.1.23.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, thusapiṇḍaṃ datvā pāṇikāya paṭibāhetvā kāḷavaṇṇaṃ nipātetun”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.1.23.eng: “I allow you to apply balls of husk, smooth with a trowel, and then apply the black color.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.1.24.eng: The black color still did not adhere.

pli-tv-kd16:3.1.25.pli: “anujānāmi, bhikkhave, gaṇḍumattikaṃ datvā pāṇikāya paṭibāhetvā kāḷavaṇṇaṃ nipātetun”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.1.25.eng: “I allow you to apply excreted clay, smooth with a trowel, and then apply the black color.”
pli-tv-kd16:3.1.25.comm: “Excreted clay” renders gaṇḍumattika. Sp 4.275: Gaṇḍumattikanti gaṇḍuppādagūthamattikaṁ, “Gaṇḍumattika means the clay excretions of worms.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.1.26.eng: The black color still did not adhere.

pli-tv-kd16:3.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū vihāre paṭibhānacittaṃ kārāpenti—
pli-tv-kd16:3.2.1.eng: At that time the monks from the group of six had pictures

pli-tv-kd16:3.2.2.eng: of women and men drawn in a dwelling.

pli-tv-kd16:3.2.3.pli: Manussā vihāracārikaṃ āhiṇḍantā passitvā ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-kd16:3.2.3.eng: When people walking about the dwellings saw this, they complained and criticized them,

pli-tv-kd16:3.2.4.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd16:3.2.8.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd16:3.2.9.pli: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, mālākammaṃ latākammaṃ makaradantakaṃ pañcapaṭikan”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.2.9.eng: I allow you to make garland patterns, creeper patterns, shark-teeth patterns, and the fivefold pattern.”
pli-tv-kd16:3.2.9.comm: “A shark-teeth pattern” renders makaradantaka, literally, “like the teeth of a makara”. In later Buddhism the makara is the name of a mythological marine animal, but what it refers to in this context is not clear. According to Sp-yoj 4.243 makara is the name of a certain species of fish: Makaradantaketi makaranāmakassa macchassa dantasadise dante, “Teeth like the teeth of a fish called makara.” Vin-vn-ṭ 3048, Makaradantakanti girikūṭākāraṁ, “Makaradantaka means making (a design) like the peak of a hill.” PED suggests “the tooth of a swordfish”, but apparently swordfish do not have teeth. Given that the makara were fearsome creatures and that their teeth looked like the peak of a hill, presumably meaning that their teeth were pointed, “shark teeth” seems like a reasonable guess. “The fivefold pattern” renders pañcapaṭika. Vmv 4.299: Pāḷiyaṁ pañcapaṭikanti jātiādipañcappakāravaṇṇamaṭṭhaṁ, “Pañcapaṭika in the canonical text means treated with the color of the five kinds, starting with jasmine.” The meaning is not clear. It seems unlikely to me, however, that it should refer to colors, since such have just been listed.

pli-tv-kd16:3.3.0.eng: 5. The allowance for foundations of bricks, etc.

pli-tv-kd16:3.3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena vihārā nīcavatthukā honti, udakena otthariyyanti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.3.1.eng: At that time the dwellings were built on a low base. They were flooded.

pli-tv-kd16:3.3.3.eng: “I allow you to raise the base.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.3.5.eng: “I allow you to construct three kinds of raised foundations:

pli-tv-kd16:3.3.6.eng: raised foundations of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.3.7.eng: It was difficult to get up to the dwelling.

pli-tv-kd16:3.3.9.eng: stairs of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.3.10.eng: People fell down while climbing the stairs.

pli-tv-kd16:3.3.12.pli: Tena kho pana samayena vihārā āḷakamandā honti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.3.12.eng: At that time the dwellings were accessible to the public.
pli-tv-kd16:3.3.12.comm: “Accessible to the public” renders āḷakamandā. In the Suttas, āḷakamandā is a name for the capital city of the devas. In the present context, however, the meaning must be something else, albeit perhaps semantically related. Sp 4.300: Ekaṅgaṇā manussābhikiṇṇā, “A single open space, thronged with people.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.3.13.eng: The monks were embarrassed to lie down there.

pli-tv-kd16:3.3.16.eng: People lifted them up and looked in.

pli-tv-kd16:3.3.18.eng: People looked over the half walls.

pli-tv-kd16:3.3.20.eng: rectangular rooms, long rooms, and upper rooms.”
pli-tv-kd16:3.3.20.comm: Sp 4.300: Sivikāgabbhoti caturassagabbho, “Sivikāgabbha means a rectangular room.” Sp 4.300: Nāḷikāgabbhoti vitthārato diguṇatiguṇāyāmo dīghagabbho, “Nāḷikāgabbha means a long room, twice or three times as long as it is wide.” Sp 4.300: Hammiyagabbhoti ākāsatale kūṭāgāragabbho vā muṇḍacchadanagabbho vā, “Hammiyagabbha means a room on the roof, either with a peaked roof or with a flat roof.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.3.21.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū khuddake vihāre majjhe gabbhaṃ karonti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.3.21.eng: On one occasion the monks made a room in the middle of a small dwelling.

pli-tv-kd16:3.3.22.eng: There was no access around the room.
pli-tv-kd16:3.3.22.comm: Vmv 4.300: Upacāro na hotīti gabbhassa bahi samantā anuparigamanassa okāso nappahoti, “Upacāro na hoti means there was insufficient space for walking all the way around outside the room.” For the rendering “access” for upacāra, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd16:3.3.24.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, khuddake vihāre ekamantaṃ gabbhaṃ kātuṃ, mahallake majjhe”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.3.24.eng: “In a small dwelling you should make the room on the side, but in a large dwelling in the middle.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.4.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena vihārassa kuṭṭapādo jīrati.
pli-tv-kd16:3.4.1.eng: At that time the base of the wall of a certain dwelling was deteriorating.

pli-tv-kd16:3.4.5.comm: “A protection screen” and “plastering” render parittāṇakiṭika and uddasudha respectively. Sp 4.300: Parittāṇakiṭikanti vassaparittāṇatthaṁ kiṭikaṁ. Uddasudhanti vacchakagomayena ceva chārikāya ca saddhiṁ madditamattikaṁ, “Parittāṇakiṭika means a screen for the purpose of protection against the rain. Uddasudha means clay mixed with calf-manure and ash.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.4.6.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa bhikkhuno tiṇacchadanā ahi khandhe patati.
pli-tv-kd16:3.4.6.eng: On one occasion a snake fell from the grass roof onto the shoulder of a certain monk.

pli-tv-kd16:3.4.8.eng: Other monks ran up to him and asked him

pli-tv-kd16:3.4.10.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhūnaṃ etamatthaṃ ārocesi.

pli-tv-kd16:3.5.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū mañcapādepi pīṭhapādepi thavikāyo laggenti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.5.1.eng: At that time the monks hung their bags from the legs of the beds and benches.

pli-tv-kd16:3.5.4.comm: Bhittikhilaṁ nāgadantakaṁ, literally, “A wall peg and an elephant tusk”. These are different kinds of pegs, and I have not tried to differentiate between them.

pli-tv-kd16:3.5.5.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū mañcepi pīṭhepi cīvaraṃ nikkhipanti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.5.5.eng: At that time the monks lay their robes on their beds and benches.

pli-tv-kd16:3.5.8.eng: “I allow bamboo robe racks and clotheslines in the dwellings.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.5.9.pli: Tena kho pana samayena vihārā anāḷindakā honti appaṭissaraṇā.
pli-tv-kd16:3.5.9.eng: At that time the dwellings were not protected by porches.
pli-tv-kd16:3.5.9.comm: Sp 4.300: Āḷindo nāma pamukhaṁ vuccati, “The forecourt is called an āḷinda.” In other words, this seems to refer to an entrance area with a roof.

pli-tv-kd16:3.5.11.eng: “I allow porches, screened doorsteps, encircling corridors, and entrance roofs.”
pli-tv-kd16:3.5.11.comm: “Screened doorstep” renders paghana. Sp 4.300: Paghanaṁ nāma yaṁ nikkhamantā ca pavisantā ca pādehi hananti, tassa vihāradvāre ubhato kuṭṭaṁ nīharitvā katapadesassetaṁ adhivacanaṁ, “Where those who leave and enter stomp their feet is called a paghana. This is a word for a place made at the door to the dwelling, having removed the wall on both sides.” Sp-ṭ 4.300 further explains this as follows: Ubhato kuṭṭaṁ nīharitvā katapadesassāti yathā antodvārasamīpe nisinnehi ujukaṁ bahi oloketuṁ na sakkā hoti, evaṁ ubhohi passehi kuṭṭaṁ nīharitvā abhimukhe bhittiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā katapadesassa, “The place made (…) having removed the wall on both sides means: just as one seated near the inside of the door is unable to see straight outside, so it is for the place made after removing the wall from both sides and building a wall in front.” “Encircling corridor” renders pakuṭṭa. Sp 4.300: Pakuṭṭanti majjhe gabbhassa samantā pariyāgāro vuccati, “A corridor on all sides of a room in the middle is called a pakuṭṭa.” “Entrance roof” osāraka. Sp 4.300: Osārakanti anāḷindake vihāre vaṁsaṁ datvā tato daṇḍake osāretvā katachadanapamukhaṁ, “Osāraka means: for a dwelling without a porch, one makes a roof in front with sticks fixed to a bamboo pole.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.5.13.eng: The monks were embarrassed to lie down there.

pli-tv-kd16:3.5.14.comm: Sp 4.300: Saṁsāraṇakiṭiko nāma cakkalayutto kiṭiko, “Saṁsāraṇakiṭika means a screen connected to wheels.” Sp-ṭ 4.300: Cakkalayutto kiṭikoti kavāṭaṁ viya vivaraṇathakanasukhatthaṁ cakkalabandhakiṭikaṁ, “Cakkalayutto kiṭika means a screen fixed to wheels for the purpose of easy opening and closing, like a door.” Vmv 4.300: Pāḷiyaṁ ugghāṭanakiṭikanti āpaṇādīsu anatthikakāle ukkhipitvā, upari ca bandhitvā pacchā otaraṇakiṭikaṁ, kappasīsehi vā upatthambhanīhi ukkhipitvā pacchā otaraṇakiṭikampi, “Ugghāṭanakiṭika, in the Canonical text, means: outside of business hours, having lifted it up onto a shop, etc., having fixed it at the top, then lowering the screen; or having raised it with a post and a bolt socket, then lowering the screen.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.6.0.eng: 6. The allowance for an assembly hall

pli-tv-kd16:3.6.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū ajjhokāse bhattavissaggaṃ karontā sītenapi uṇhenapi kilamanti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.6.1.eng: At that time the monks were taking their meals outside. They were troubled by the cold and the heat.

pli-tv-kd16:3.6.4.eng: The assembly halls were built on a low base. They were flooded.

pli-tv-kd16:3.6.5.eng: “I allow you to raise the base.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.6.7.eng: “I allow you to construct three kinds of raised foundations:

pli-tv-kd16:3.6.8.eng: raised foundations of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.6.9.eng: It was difficult to get up to the assembly halls.

pli-tv-kd16:3.6.11.eng: stairs of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.6.12.eng: People fell down while climbing the stairs.

pli-tv-kd16:3.6.14.eng: Grass and dust fell into the assembly halls.

pli-tv-kd16:3.6.15.eng: “I allow you to firm up the structure and then to plaster it inside and outside, including:

pli-tv-kd16:3.6.16.pli: setavaṇṇaṃ kāḷavaṇṇaṃ gerukaparikammaṃ mālākammaṃ latākammaṃ makaradantakaṃ pañcapaṭikaṃ cīvaravaṃsaṃ cīvararajjun”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.6.16.eng: treating with white color, black color, and red ocher; making garland patterns, creeper patterns, shark-teeth patterns, and the fivefold pattern; putting up bamboo robe racks and clotheslines.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.6.17.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū ajjhokāse chamāya cīvaraṃ pattharanti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.6.17.eng: At that time the monks spread their robes on the ground outside.

pli-tv-kd16:3.6.20.eng: “I allow bamboo robe racks and clotheslines outside.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.7.2.eng: “I allow sheds and roof covers for the drinking water.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.7.3.eng: The drinking-water sheds were built on a low base. They were flooded.
pli-tv-kd16:3.7.3.comm: “Drinking-water sheds” renders pāniyasālā. For further discussion of sālā, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd16:3.7.4.eng: “I allow you to raise the base.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.7.6.eng: “I allow you to construct three kinds of raised foundations:

pli-tv-kd16:3.7.7.eng: raised foundations of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.7.8.eng: It was difficult to get up to the sheds.

pli-tv-kd16:3.7.10.eng: stairs of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.7.11.eng: People fell down while climbing the stairs.

pli-tv-kd16:3.7.13.eng: Grass and dust fell into the drinking-water sheds.

pli-tv-kd16:3.7.14.eng: “I allow you to firm up the structure and then to plaster it inside and outside, including:

pli-tv-kd16:3.7.15.pli: setavaṇṇaṃ kāḷavaṇṇaṃ gerukaparikammaṃ mālākammaṃ latākammaṃ makaradantakaṃ pañcapaṭikaṃ cīvaravaṃsaṃ cīvararajjun”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.7.15.eng: treating with white color, black color, and red ocher; making garland patterns, creeper patterns, shark-teeth patterns, and the fivefold pattern; putting up bamboo robe racks and clotheslines.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.7.16.eng: There were no vessels for the drinking water.
pli-tv-kd16:3.7.16.comm: Sp 4.301: Pānīyabhājananti pivantānaṁ pānīyadānabhājanaṁ, “Pānīyabhājana means vessel for taking the drinking water for those who are drinking.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.8.0.eng: 7. The allowance for encircling walls, etc.

pli-tv-kd16:3.8.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena vihārā aparikkhittā honti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.8.1.eng: At that time the dwellings were unenclosed.

pli-tv-kd16:3.8.3.eng: “I allow you to make enclosures with three kinds of encircling walls:

pli-tv-kd16:3.8.4.eng: brick walls, stone walls, and wooden walls.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.8.5.comm: For the rendering “gatehouse” for koṭṭhaka, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd16:3.8.7.eng: They built the gatehouses on a low base. They were flooded.

pli-tv-kd16:3.8.8.eng: “I allow you to raise the base.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.8.10.pli: “anujānāmi, bhikkhave, kavāṭaṃ piṭṭhasaṅghāṭaṃ udukkhalikaṃ uttarapāsakaṃ aggaḷavaṭṭiṃ kapisīsakaṃ sūcikaṃ ghaṭikaṃ tāḷacchiddaṃ āviñchanacchiddaṃ āviñchanarajjun”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.8.10.eng: “I allow doors, door frames, lower hinges, upper hinges, door jambs, bolt sockets, bolts, latches, keyholes, door-pulling holes, and door-pulling ropes.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.8.11.eng: Grass and dust fell into the gatehouses.

pli-tv-kd16:3.8.12.eng: “I allow you to firm up the structure and then plaster it inside and outside, including:

pli-tv-kd16:3.8.13.pli: setavaṇṇaṃ kāḷavaṇṇaṃ gerukaparikammaṃ mālākammaṃ latākammaṃ makaradantakaṃ pañcapaṭikan”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.8.13.eng: treating with white color, black color, and red ocher; making garland patterns, creeper patterns, shark-teeth patterns, and the fivefold pattern.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.8.14.pli: Tena kho pana samayena pariveṇaṃ cikkhallaṃ hoti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.8.14.comm: For an explanation of rendering pariveṇa as “yard”, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd16:3.8.16.eng: “I allow you to cover them with gravel.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.8.17.eng: They were unable to do it.

pli-tv-kd16:3.8.18.eng: “I allow you to lay paving stones.”
pli-tv-kd16:3.8.18.comm: Or “slabs of stone”, padarasila. See Bu Pc 18:2.3.5 where padara means “floor boards”.

pli-tv-kd16:3.9.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū pariveṇe tahaṃ tahaṃ aggiṭṭhānaṃ karonti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.9.1.eng: At that time the monks made fireplaces here and there in the yards.

pli-tv-kd16:3.9.4.eng: “I allow you to build water-boiling sheds out of the way.”
pli-tv-kd16:3.9.4.comm: For a further discussion of aggisālā and sālā, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd16:3.9.5.eng: They built the water-boiling sheds on a low base. They were flooded.

pli-tv-kd16:3.9.6.eng: “I allow you to raise the base.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.9.8.eng: “I allow you to construct three kinds of raised foundations:

pli-tv-kd16:3.9.9.eng: raised foundations of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.9.10.eng: It was difficult to get up to the water-boiling sheds.

pli-tv-kd16:3.9.12.eng: stairs of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.9.13.eng: People fell down while climbing the stairs.

pli-tv-kd16:3.9.15.eng: The water-boiling sheds didn’t have doors.

pli-tv-kd16:3.9.16.pli: “anujānāmi, bhikkhave, kavāṭaṃ piṭṭhasaṅghāṭaṃ udukkhalikaṃ uttarapāsakaṃ aggaḷavaṭṭiṃ kapisīsakaṃ sūcikaṃ ghaṭikaṃ tāḷacchiddaṃ āviñchanacchiddaṃ āviñchanarajjun”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.9.16.eng: “I allow doors, door frames, lower hinges, upper hinges, door jambs, bolt sockets, bolts, latches, keyholes, door-pulling holes, and door-pulling ropes.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.9.17.eng: Grass and dust fell into the water-boiling sheds.

pli-tv-kd16:3.9.18.eng: “I allow you to firm up the structure and then to plaster it inside and outside, including:

pli-tv-kd16:3.9.19.pli: setavaṇṇaṃ kāḷavaṇṇaṃ gerukaparikammaṃ mālākammaṃ latākammaṃ makaradantakaṃ pañcapaṭikaṃ cīvaravaṃsaṃ cīvararajjun”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.9.19.eng: treating with white color, black color, and red ocher; making garland patterns, creeper patterns, shark-teeth patterns, and the fivefold pattern; putting up bamboo robe racks and clotheslines.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.10.0.eng: 8. The allowance to enclose a monastery

pli-tv-kd16:3.10.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena ārāmo aparikkhitto hoti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.10.1.eng: At that time the monasteries were unenclosed.

pli-tv-kd16:3.10.2.eng: Goats and domesticated animals harmed the saplings.

pli-tv-kd16:3.10.4.eng: “I allow you to make three kinds of enclosures:

pli-tv-kd16:3.10.5.eng: enclosures of bamboo, enclosures of thorny branches, and trenches.”
pli-tv-kd16:3.10.5.comm: Reading kaṇṭakīvāṭa and parikha with the PTS edition.

pli-tv-kd16:3.10.7.eng: Goats and domesticated animals harmed the saplings just the same.

pli-tv-kd16:3.10.8.pli: “anujānāmi, bhikkhave, koṭṭhakaṃ apesiṃ yamakakavāṭaṃ toraṇaṃ palighan”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.10.8.eng: “I allow gatehouses, gates of wood and thorny branches, double doors, arches, and crossbars.”
pli-tv-kd16:3.10.8.comm: “Gates of wood and thorny branches” renders apesi. Sp 4.303: Apesīti dīghadārumhi khāṇuke pavesetvā kaṇṭakasākhāhi vinandhitvā kataṁ dvārathakanakaṁ, “Apesi means a closing gate that is made by entering stakes into a long piece of wood and covering it with thorny branches.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.10.9.eng: Grass and dust fell into the gatehouses.

pli-tv-kd16:3.10.10.eng: “I allow you to firm up the structure and then plaster it inside and outside, including:

pli-tv-kd16:3.10.11.pli: setavaṇṇaṃ kāḷavaṇṇaṃ gerukaparikammaṃ mālākammaṃ latākammaṃ makaradantakaṃ pañcapaṭikan”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.10.11.eng: treating with white color, black color, and red ocher; making garland patterns, creeper patterns, shark-teeth patterns, and the fivefold pattern.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.10.13.eng: “I allow you to cover them with gravel.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.10.14.eng: They were unable to do it.

pli-tv-kd16:3.10.15.eng: “I allow you to lay paving stones.”
pli-tv-kd16:3.10.15.comm: Or “slabs of stone”, padarasila. See Bu Pc 18:2.3.5 where padara means “floor boards”.

pli-tv-kd16:3.11.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro saṅghassa atthāya sudhāmattikālepanaṃ pāsādaṃ kāretukāmo hoti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.11.1.eng: On one occasion King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha wanted to build a stilt house smeared with clay plaster for the Sangha.

pli-tv-kd16:3.11.3.pli: “kiṃ nu kho bhagavatā chadanaṃ anuññātaṃ, kiṃ ananuññātan”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:3.11.3.eng: “Which roofing materials has the Buddha allowed and which hasn’t he?”

pli-tv-kd16:3.11.5.eng: “I allow five kinds of roofing materials:

pli-tv-kd16:3.11.6.eng: tiles, slate, plaster, grass, and leaves.”

pli-tv-kd16:3.11.7.eng: The first section for recitation is finished.

pli-tv-kd16:4.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati rājagahakassa seṭṭhissa bhaginipatiko hoti.
pli-tv-kd16:4.1.1.eng: At that time the householder Anāthapiṇḍika had a brother in law in Rājagaha who was a wealthy merchant.

pli-tv-kd16:4.1.2.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati rājagahaṃ agamāsi kenacideva karaṇīyena.
pli-tv-kd16:4.1.2.eng: On one occasion when Anāthapiṇḍika was in Rājagaha on business,

pli-tv-kd16:4.1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rājagahakena seṭṭhinā svātanāya buddhappamukho saṅgho nimantito hoti.
pli-tv-kd16:4.1.3.eng: that merchant had invited the Sangha headed by the Buddha for the meal on the following day.

pli-tv-kd16:4.1.4.pli: Atha kho rājagahako seṭṭhī dāse ca kammakāre ca āṇāpesi—
pli-tv-kd16:4.1.4.eng: The merchant was telling his slaves and workers

pli-tv-kd16:4.1.5.pli: “tena hi, bhaṇe, kālasseva uṭṭhāya yāguyo pacatha, bhattāni pacatha, sūpāni sampādetha, uttaribhaṅgāni sampādethā”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:4.1.5.eng: to get up early, to cook rice and congee, and to prepare various kinds of curry.

pli-tv-kd16:4.1.7.pli: “pubbe khvāyaṃ gahapati mayi āgate sabbakiccāni nikkhipitvā mamaññeva saddhiṃ paṭisammodati.
pli-tv-kd16:4.1.7.eng: “When I’ve arrived here previously, this householder put aside all his business to greet me.

pli-tv-kd16:4.1.8.pli: Sodānāyaṃ vikkhittarūpo dāse ca kammakāre ca āṇāpesi—
pli-tv-kd16:4.1.8.eng: But this time he’s all over the place,

pli-tv-kd16:4.1.9.pli: ‘tena hi, bhaṇe, kālasseva uṭṭhāya yāguyo pacatha, bhattāni pacatha, sūpāni sampādetha, uttaribhaṅgāni sampādethā’ti.
pli-tv-kd16:4.1.9.eng: telling his workers what to do.

pli-tv-kd16:4.1.10.pli: Kiṃ nu kho imassa gahapatissa āvāho vā bhavissati, vivāho vā bhavissati, mahāyañño vā paccupaṭṭhito, rājā vā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro nimantito svātanāya saddhiṃ balakāyenā”ti?
pli-tv-kd16:4.1.10.eng: Is he preparing for a wedding or a great sacrifice, or has he invited King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha and the army for a meal?”

pli-tv-kd16:4.2.1.pli: Atha kho rājagahako seṭṭhī dāse ca kammakāre ca āṇāpetvā yena anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā anāthapiṇḍikena gahapatinā saddhiṃ paṭisammoditvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd16:4.2.1.eng: When the merchant was finished with instructing his workers, he went up to Anāthapiṇḍika, greeted him, and sat down.

pli-tv-kd16:4.2.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho rājagahakaṃ seṭṭhiṃ anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd16:4.2.2.eng: Anāthapiṇḍika then told him what he had observed

pli-tv-kd16:4.2.3.pli: “pubbe kho tvaṃ, gahapati, mayi āgate sabbakiccāni nikkhipitvā mamaññeva saddhiṃ paṭisammodasi.

pli-tv-kd16:4.2.4.pli: Sodāni tvaṃ vikkhittarūpo dāse ca kammakāre ca āṇāpesi—

pli-tv-kd16:4.2.5.pli: ‘tena hi, bhaṇe, kālasseva uṭṭhāya yāguyo pacatha, bhattāni pacatha, sūpāni sampādetha, uttaribhaṅgāni sampādethā’ti.

pli-tv-kd16:4.2.6.pli: Kiṃ nu kho te, gahapati, āvāho vā bhavissati, vivāho vā bhavissati, mahāyañño vā paccupaṭṭhito, rājā vā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro nimantito svātanāya saddhiṃ balakāyenā”ti?
pli-tv-kd16:4.2.6.eng: and asked him what was happening.

pli-tv-kd16:4.2.7.pli: “Na me, gahapati, āvāho vā bhavissati, nāpi vivāho vā bhavissati, nāpi rājā vā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro nimantito svātanāya saddhiṃ balakāyena;
pli-tv-kd16:4.2.7.eng: The merchant replied, “I’m not preparing for a wedding, nor have I invited King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha and the army.

pli-tv-kd16:4.2.8.eng: I’m preparing for a great sacrifice.

pli-tv-kd16:4.2.9.eng: I’ve invited the Sangha headed by the Buddha for a meal tomorrow.”

pli-tv-kd16:4.2.16.pli: “Ghosopi kho eso, gahapati, dullabho lokasmiṃ yadidaṃ—

pli-tv-kd16:4.2.18.pli: Sakkā nu kho, gahapati, imaṃ kālaṃ taṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhan”ti?
pli-tv-kd16:4.2.18.eng: Is it possible right now to go and visit that Buddha, that fully awakened and perfected one?”

pli-tv-kd16:4.2.19.pli: “Akālo kho, gahapati, imaṃ kālaṃ taṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ.
pli-tv-kd16:4.2.19.eng: “Now is the wrong time to visit the Buddha.

pli-tv-kd16:4.2.20.pli: Svedāni tvaṃ kālena taṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissasi arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhan”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:4.2.20.eng: Tomorrow morning is a good time.”

pli-tv-kd16:4.2.21.eng: Because he went to bed preoccupied with the Buddha—

pli-tv-kd16:4.2.22.pli: svedānāhaṃ kālena taṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissāmi arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhanti—
pli-tv-kd16:4.2.22.eng: “Tomorrow morning I will go and visit that Buddha, that fully awakened and perfected one!”—

pli-tv-kd16:4.2.23.pli: buddhagatāya satiyā nipajjitvā rattiyā sudaṃ tikkhattuṃ vuṭṭhāsi pabhātaṃ maññamāno.
pli-tv-kd16:4.2.23.eng: he got up three times during the night thinking it was light.

pli-tv-kd16:4.3.1.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati yena sivakadvāraṃ tenupasaṅkami.
pli-tv-kd16:4.3.1.eng: Anāthapiṇḍika then went to the Sivaka gate,

pli-tv-kd16:4.3.3.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa nagaramhā nikkhantassa āloko antaradhāyi, andhakāro pāturahosi, bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃso udapādi;
pli-tv-kd16:4.3.3.eng: Then, as he was leaving town, the light disappeared and darkness descended. Paralyzed with fear and getting goosebumps all over,

pli-tv-kd16:4.3.5.pli: Atha kho sivako yakkho antarahito saddamanussāvesi—
pli-tv-kd16:4.3.5.eng: But then the invisible spirit Sivaka spoke up:

pli-tv-kd16:4.3.7.eng: A hundred carriages drawn by mules,

pli-tv-kd16:4.3.10.eng: None is worth a sixteenth part

pli-tv-kd16:4.3.13.eng: Going forward is better for you than going back.”

pli-tv-kd16:4.3.14.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa andhakāro antaradhāyi, āloko pāturahosi.
pli-tv-kd16:4.3.14.eng: The light returned, the darkness disappeared,

pli-tv-kd16:4.3.15.pli: Yaṃ ahosi bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃso so paṭippassambhi.

pli-tv-kd16:4.3.18.pli: anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa āloko antaradhāyi, andhakāro pāturahosi, bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃso udapādi, tatova puna nivattitukāmo ahosi.
pli-tv-kd16:4.3.18.eng: the light disappeared and he was paralyzed with fear,

pli-tv-kd16:4.3.19.pli: Tatiyampi kho sivako yakkho antarahito saddamanussāvesi—
pli-tv-kd16:4.3.19.eng: upon which the spirit proclaimed the same verses. And on both occasions the light returned, the darkness disappeared, and his fear subsided.

pli-tv-kd16:4.3.28.pli: Tatiyampi kho anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa andhakāro antaradhāyi, āloko pāturahosi, yaṃ ahosi bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃso, so paṭippassambhi.

pli-tv-kd16:4.4.1.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati yena sītavanaṃ tenupasaṅkami.
pli-tv-kd16:4.4.1.eng: Anāthapiṇḍika then went to the Sītavana, the Cool Grove.

pli-tv-kd16:4.4.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ paccuṭṭhāya ajjhokāse caṅkamati.
pli-tv-kd16:4.4.2.eng: Just then the Buddha was doing walking meditation outside, having gotten up early in the morning.

pli-tv-kd16:4.4.3.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
pli-tv-kd16:4.4.3.eng: When the Buddha saw Anāthapiṇḍika coming,

pli-tv-kd16:4.4.4.pli: Disvāna caṅkamā orohitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd16:4.4.4.eng: he stepped down from the walking path, sat down on the prepared seat,

pli-tv-kd16:4.4.5.pli: Nisajja kho bhagavā anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd16:4.4.8.eng: “The Buddha is calling me by name!”

pli-tv-kd16:4.4.9.pli: haṭṭho udaggo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd16:4.4.9.eng: and glad and joyful he went up to him, bowed down with his head at the Buddha’s feet, and said,

pli-tv-kd16:4.4.10.eng: “Sir, I hope you have slept well?”

pli-tv-kd16:4.4.11.comm: This and the following verse are also found at SN 10.8:12.1 and AN 3.35:8.1.

pli-tv-kd16:4.4.13.eng: Who’s not soiled among worldly pleasures,

pli-tv-kd16:4.4.14.eng: But is cool and without ownership.

pli-tv-kd16:4.4.16.eng: After removing distress from the heart,

pli-tv-kd16:4.5.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa anupubbiṃ kathaṃ kathesi, seyyathidaṃ—
pli-tv-kd16:4.5.1.eng: The Buddha then gave him a progressive talk—

pli-tv-kd16:4.5.2.pli: dānakathaṃ sīlakathaṃ saggakathaṃ, kāmānaṃ ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṅkilesaṃ, nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ pakāsesi.
pli-tv-kd16:4.5.2.eng: on generosity, morality, and heaven; on the downside, degradation, and defilement of worldly pleasures; and he revealed the benefits of renunciation.

pli-tv-kd16:4.5.3.pli: Yadā bhagavā aññāsi anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ kallacittaṃ muducittaṃ vinīvaraṇacittaṃ udaggacittaṃ pasannacittaṃ, atha yā buddhānaṃ sāmukkaṃsikā dhammadesanā taṃ pakāsesi—
pli-tv-kd16:4.5.3.eng: When the Buddha knew that his mind was ready, supple, without hindrances, joyful, and confident, he revealed the teaching unique to the Buddhas:

pli-tv-kd16:4.5.4.eng: suffering, its origin, its end, and the path.

pli-tv-kd16:4.5.5.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma suddhaṃ vatthaṃ apagatakāḷakaṃ sammadeva rajanaṃ paṭiggaṇheyya;
pli-tv-kd16:4.5.5.eng: And just as a clean and stainless cloth absorbs dye properly,

pli-tv-kd16:4.5.6.pli: evameva anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa tasmiṃyeva āsane virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādi—
pli-tv-kd16:4.5.6.eng: so too, while he was sitting right there, Anāthapiṇḍika experienced the stainless vision of the Truth:

pli-tv-kd16:4.5.7.eng: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.”

pli-tv-kd16:4.5.8.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati diṭṭhadhammo pattadhammo viditadhammo pariyogāḷhadhammo tiṇṇavicikiccho vigatakathaṅkatho vesārajjappatto aparappaccayo satthusāsane bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd16:4.5.8.eng: He had seen the Truth, had reached, understood, and penetrated it. He had gone beyond doubt and uncertainty, had attained to confidence, and had become independent of others in the Teacher’s instruction. He then said to the Buddha,

pli-tv-kd16:4.5.10.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya—
pli-tv-kd16:4.5.10.eng: Just as one might set upright what’s overturned, or reveal what’s hidden, or show the way to one who’s lost, or bring a lamp into the darkness

pli-tv-kd16:4.5.11.eng: so that one with eyes might see what’s there—

pli-tv-kd16:4.5.12.eng: just so has the Buddha made the Teaching clear in many ways.

pli-tv-kd16:4.5.13.pli: Esāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi, dhammañca, bhikkhusaṅghañca.
pli-tv-kd16:4.5.13.eng: I go for refuge to the Buddha, the Teaching, and the Sangha of monks.

pli-tv-kd16:4.5.14.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gataṃ.
pli-tv-kd16:4.5.14.eng: Please accept me as a lay follower who’s gone for refuge for life.

pli-tv-kd16:4.5.15.pli: Adhivāsetu ca me, bhante, bhagavā svātanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:4.5.15.eng: And please accept tomorrow’s meal from me together with the Sangha of monks.”

pli-tv-kd16:4.5.16.eng: The Buddha consented by remaining silent.

pli-tv-kd16:4.5.17.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati bhagavato adhivāsanaṃ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd16:4.5.17.eng: Knowing that the Buddha had consented, Anāthapiṇḍika got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left.

pli-tv-kd16:4.6.2.pli: “anāthapiṇḍikena kira gahapatinā svātanāya buddhappamukho saṅgho nimantito”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:4.6.2.eng: that Anāthapiṇḍika had invited the Sangha headed by the Buddha for the meal on the following day.

pli-tv-kd16:4.6.3.pli: Atha kho rājagahako seṭṭhī anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd16:4.6.4.pli: “tayā kira, gahapati, svātanāya buddhappamukho saṅgho nimantito.
pli-tv-kd16:4.6.4.eng: “You’ve invited the Sangha headed by the Buddha,

pli-tv-kd16:4.6.6.pli: Demi te, gahapati, veyyāyikaṃ yena tvaṃ buddhappamukhassa saṅghassa bhattaṃ kareyyāsī”ti.

pli-tv-kd16:4.6.7.pli: “Alaṃ, gahapati, atthi me veyyāyikaṃ yenāhaṃ buddhappamukhassa saṅghassa bhattaṃ karissāmī”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:4.6.7.eng: “There’s no need. I have the means.”

pli-tv-kd16:4.6.8.eng: The householder association of Rājagaha heard

pli-tv-kd16:4.6.9.pli: “anāthapiṇḍikena kira gahapatinā svātanāya buddhappamukho saṅgho nimantito”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:4.6.9.eng: that Anāthapiṇḍika had invited the Sangha headed by the Buddha for a meal on the following day.

pli-tv-kd16:4.6.10.pli: Atha kho rājagahako negamo anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd16:4.6.11.pli: “tayā kira, gahapati, svātanāya buddhappamukho saṅgho nimantito.
pli-tv-kd16:4.6.11.eng: “You’ve invited the Sangha headed by the Buddha,

pli-tv-kd16:4.6.13.pli: Demi te, gahapati, veyyāyikaṃ yena tvaṃ buddhappamukhassa saṅghassa bhattaṃ kareyyāsī”ti.

pli-tv-kd16:4.6.15.pli: atthi me veyyāyikaṃ yenāhaṃ buddhappamukhassa saṅghassa bhattaṃ karissāmī”ti.

pli-tv-kd16:4.6.16.pli: Assosi kho rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro—
pli-tv-kd16:4.6.16.eng: King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha heard

pli-tv-kd16:4.6.17.pli: “anāthapiṇḍikena kira gahapatinā svātanāya buddhappamukho saṅgho nimantito”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:4.6.17.eng: that Anāthapiṇḍika had invited the Sangha headed by the Buddha for a meal on the following day.

pli-tv-kd16:4.6.18.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd16:4.6.19.pli: “tayā kira, gahapati, svātanāya buddhappamukho saṅgho nimantito.
pli-tv-kd16:4.6.19.eng: “You’ve invited the Sangha headed by the Buddha,

pli-tv-kd16:4.6.21.pli: Demi te, gahapati, veyyāyikaṃ yena tvaṃ buddhappamukhassa saṅghassa bhattaṃ kareyyāsī”ti.

pli-tv-kd16:4.6.23.pli: atthi me veyyāyikaṃ yenāhaṃ buddhappamukhassa saṅghassa bhattaṃ karissāmī”ti.

pli-tv-kd16:4.7.1.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati tassā rattiyā accayena rājagahakassa seṭṭhissa nivesane paṇītaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ paṭiyādāpetvā bhagavato kālaṃ ārocāpesi—
pli-tv-kd16:4.7.1.eng: The following morning, in that wealthy merchant’s house, Anāthapiṇḍika had various kinds of fine foods prepared. He then had the Buddha informed

pli-tv-kd16:4.7.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena rājagahakassa seṭṭhissa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena.
pli-tv-kd16:4.7.3.eng: The Buddha robed up, took his bowl and robe, and went to that merchant’s house where he sat down on the prepared seat together with the Sangha of monks.

pli-tv-kd16:4.7.4.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati buddhappamukhaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappetvā sampavāretvā, bhagavantaṃ bhuttāviṃ onītapattapāṇiṃ, ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd16:4.7.4.eng: Anāthapiṇḍika then personally served the various kinds of fine foods to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha. When the Buddha had finished his meal and had washed his hands and bowl, Anāthapiṇḍika sat down to one side

pli-tv-kd16:4.7.5.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd16:4.7.6.pli: “adhivāsetu me, bhante, bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ vassāvāsaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:4.7.6.eng: “Sir, please spend the rainy-season residence at Sāvatthī together with the Sangha of monks.”

pli-tv-kd16:4.7.9.pli: Atha kho bhagavā anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṃsetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd16:4.7.9.eng: Then, after instructing, inspiring, and gladdening him with a teaching, the Buddha got up from his seat and left.

pli-tv-kd16:4.8.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati bahumitto hoti bahusahāyo ādeyyavāco.
pli-tv-kd16:4.8.1.eng: After finishing his business in Rājagaha,

pli-tv-kd16:4.8.2.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati rājagahe taṃ karaṇīyaṃ tīretvā yena sāvatthi tena pakkāmi.

pli-tv-kd16:4.8.3.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati antarāmagge manusse āṇāpesi—
pli-tv-kd16:4.8.3.eng: Now at that time Anāthapiṇḍika had many friends and acquaintances who took his advice. On his way to Sāvatthī he told people

pli-tv-kd16:4.8.4.pli: “ārāme, ayyā, karotha, vihāre patiṭṭhāpetha, dānāni paṭṭhapetha.
pli-tv-kd16:4.8.4.eng: to establish monasteries, build dwellings, and prepare offerings, saying,

pli-tv-kd16:4.8.6.pli: So ca mayā bhagavā nimantito iminā maggena āgacchissatī”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:4.8.6.eng: He’s been invited by me and will be traveling this way.”

pli-tv-kd16:4.8.7.pli: Atha kho te manussā anāthapiṇḍikena gahapatinā uyyojitā ārāme akaṃsu, vihāre patiṭṭhāpesuṃ, dānāni paṭṭhapesuṃ.

pli-tv-kd16:4.8.8.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati sāvatthiṃ gantvā samantā sāvatthiṃ anuvilokesi—
pli-tv-kd16:4.8.8.eng: When he arrived at Sāvatthī, Anāthapiṇḍika searched all over the town for a place for the Buddha to stay, thinking,

pli-tv-kd16:4.8.10.pli: Yaṃ assa gāmato neva atidūre na accāsanne, gamanāgamanasampannaṃ, atthikānaṃ atthikānaṃ manussānaṃ abhikkamanīyaṃ, divā appākiṇṇaṃ, rattiṃ appasaddaṃ, appanigghosaṃ, vijanavātaṃ, manussarāhasseyyakaṃ, paṭisallānasāruppan”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:4.8.10.eng: that’s neither too far from habitation nor too close, that has good access roads and is easily accessible for people who seek him, that has few people during the day and is quiet at night, that’s free from chatter and offers solitude, a private resting place suitable for seclusion?”

pli-tv-kd16:4.9.1.pli: Addasā kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati jetassa kumārassa uyyānaṃ—
pli-tv-kd16:4.9.1.eng: Anāthapiṇḍika saw that Prince Jeta’s park

pli-tv-kd16:4.9.2.pli: gāmato neva atidūre na accāsanne, gamanāgamanasampannaṃ, atthikānaṃ atthikānaṃ manussānaṃ abhikkamanīyaṃ, divā appākiṇṇaṃ, rattiṃ appasaddaṃ, appanigghosaṃ, vijanavātaṃ, manussarāhasseyyakaṃ, paṭisallānasāruppaṃ.

pli-tv-kd16:4.9.3.pli: Disvāna yena jeto kumāro tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā jetaṃ kumāraṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd16:4.9.3.eng: He then went to Prince Jeta and said,

pli-tv-kd16:4.9.4.eng: “Sir, please give me your park to set up a monastery.”

pli-tv-kd16:4.9.5.eng: “I wouldn’t give it away even if you covered the park with ten million gold coins.”
pli-tv-kd16:4.9.5.comm: The Pali just says koṭi, “ten million”. That this refers to gold coins, hirañña, is clear from the events that follow.

pli-tv-kd16:4.9.8.eng: They then asked judges to decide on the matter.

pli-tv-kd16:4.9.10.pli: “yato tayā, ayyaputta, aggho kato, gahito ārāmo”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:4.9.10.eng: “Sir, since you gave a price, the park is sold.”

pli-tv-kd16:4.9.11.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati sakaṭehi hiraññaṃ nibbāhāpetvā jetavanaṃ koṭisantharaṃ santharāpesi.
pli-tv-kd16:4.9.11.eng: Anāthapiṇḍika then had gold coins brought out in carts and covered the Jeta Grove with ten million coins.

pli-tv-kd16:4.10.1.pli: Sakiṃ nīhaṭaṃ hiraññaṃ thokassa okāsassa koṭṭhakasāmantā nappahoti.
pli-tv-kd16:4.10.1.eng: After yet another load had been brought out, there was still a small area near the gatehouse that was not covered.

pli-tv-kd16:4.10.2.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati manusse āṇāpesi—

pli-tv-kd16:4.10.6.pli: “na kho idaṃ orakaṃ bhavissati, yathāyaṃ gahapati tāva bahuṃ hiraññaṃ pariccajatī”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:4.10.6.eng: “This must be really worthwhile, as he’s giving up so much money.”
pli-tv-kd16:4.10.6.comm: For an explanation of the rendering “money” for hirañña, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd16:4.10.13.pli: ayaṃ kho jeto kumāro abhiññāto ñātamanusso;

pli-tv-kd16:4.10.14.pli: mahatthiko kho pana evarūpānaṃ ñātamanussānaṃ imasmiṃ dhammavinaye pasādoti—
pli-tv-kd16:4.10.14.eng: It’s very beneficial that such well-known people gain confidence in this spiritual path.”

pli-tv-kd16:4.10.15.eng: And he granted that area to Prince Jeta.

pli-tv-kd16:4.10.16.pli: Atha kho jeto kumāro tasmiṃ okāse koṭṭhakaṃ māpesi.
pli-tv-kd16:4.10.16.eng: Prince Jeta then had a gatehouse built at that place.

pli-tv-kd16:4.10.17.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati jetavane vihāre kārāpesi, pariveṇāni kārāpesi, koṭṭhake kārāpesi, upaṭṭhānasālāyo kārāpesi, aggisālāyo kārāpesi, kappiyakuṭiyo kārāpesi, vaccakuṭiyo kārāpesi, caṅkame kārāpesi, caṅkamanasālāyo kārāpesi, udapāne kārāpesi, udapānasālāyo kārāpesi, jantāghare kārāpesi, jantāgharasālāyo kārāpesi, pokkharaṇiyo kārāpesi, maṇḍape kārāpesi.
pli-tv-kd16:4.10.17.eng: But Anāthapiṇḍika had dwellings built in the Jeta Grove, and yards, gatehouses, assembly halls, water-boiling sheds, food-storage huts, restrooms, walking-meditation paths, indoor walking-meditation paths, wells, well houses, saunas, sauna sheds, ponds, and roof-covers.

pli-tv-kd16:5.1.0.eng: 10. Putting in charge of building work

pli-tv-kd16:5.1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā rājagahe yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā yena vesālī tena cārikaṃ pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd16:5.1.1.eng: When the Buddha had stayed at Rājagaha for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Vesālī.

pli-tv-kd16:5.1.2.pli: Anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno yena vesālī tadavasari.

pli-tv-kd16:5.1.3.pli: Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
pli-tv-kd16:5.1.3.eng: he stayed in the hall with the peaked roof in the Great Wood.

pli-tv-kd16:5.1.4.pli: Tena kho pana samayena manussā sakkaccaṃ navakammaṃ karonti.
pli-tv-kd16:5.1.4.eng: At that time people were doing building work out of respect.

pli-tv-kd16:5.1.5.pli: Yepi bhikkhū navakammaṃ adhiṭṭhenti tepi sakkaccaṃ upaṭṭhenti cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārena.
pli-tv-kd16:5.1.5.eng: And the monks who supervised the building work were respectfully supported with robe-cloth, almsfood, dwellings, and medicinal supplies.

pli-tv-kd16:5.1.6.pli: Atha kho aññatarassa daliddassa tunnavāyassa etadahosi—
pli-tv-kd16:5.1.6.eng: Then a certain poor tailor thought,

pli-tv-kd16:5.1.7.pli: “na kho idaṃ orakaṃ bhavissati, yathayime manussā sakkaccaṃ navakammaṃ karonti;
pli-tv-kd16:5.1.7.eng: “This must be really worthwhile, seeing as these people do building work with such respect.

pli-tv-kd16:5.1.8.eng: Why don’t I too do building work?”

pli-tv-kd16:5.1.9.pli: Atha kho so daliddo tunnavāyo sāmaṃ cikkhallaṃ madditvā iṭṭhakāyo cinitvā kuṭṭaṃ uṭṭhāpesi.
pli-tv-kd16:5.1.9.eng: He then made a mixture of mud, made bricks out of it, and built a wall.

pli-tv-kd16:5.1.10.pli: Tena akusalakena citā vaṅkā bhitti paripati.
pli-tv-kd16:5.1.10.eng: But because of his lack of skill, the wall was crooked and fell down.

pli-tv-kd16:5.1.12.pli: tatiyampi kho so daliddo tunnavāyo sāmaṃ cikkhallaṃ madditvā iṭṭhakāyo cinitvā kuṭṭaṃ uṭṭhāpesi.
pli-tv-kd16:5.1.12.eng: and a third time the same thing happened.

pli-tv-kd16:5.1.13.pli: Tena akusalakena citā vaṅkā bhitti paripati.

pli-tv-kd16:5.2.1.pli: Atha kho so daliddo tunnavāyo ujjhāyati khiyyati vipāceti—
pli-tv-kd16:5.2.1.eng: He then complained and criticized the monks,

pli-tv-kd16:5.2.2.pli: “ye imesaṃ samaṇānaṃ sakyaputtiyānaṃ denti cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṃ, te ime ovadanti anusāsanti, tesañca navakammaṃ adhiṭṭhenti.
pli-tv-kd16:5.2.2.eng: “These Sakyan monastics teach and instruct only those who give them robe-cloth, almsfood, dwellings, and medicinal supplies. They only supervise their building work.

pli-tv-kd16:5.2.4.pli: Na maṃ koci ovadati vā anusāsati vā navakammaṃ vā adhiṭṭhetī”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:5.2.4.eng: nobody teaches, instructs, or supervises me.”

pli-tv-kd16:5.2.5.pli: Assosuṃ kho bhikkhū tassa daliddassa tunnavāyassa ujjhāyantassa khiyyantassa vipācentassa.
pli-tv-kd16:5.2.5.eng: The monks heard the complaints of that poor tailor.

pli-tv-kd16:5.2.6.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ.

pli-tv-kd16:5.2.7.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etasmiṃ nidāne etasmiṃ pakaraṇe dhammiṃ kathaṃ katvā bhikkhū āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd16:5.2.7.eng: who then gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd16:5.2.8.eng: “You should put a monk in charge of the building work.

pli-tv-kd16:5.2.10.pli: ‘kinti nu kho vihāro khippaṃ pariyosānaṃ gaccheyyā’ti;
pli-tv-kd16:5.2.10.eng: to complete the dwelling as quickly as possible

pli-tv-kd16:5.2.11.eng: and should repair what’s broken or damaged.

pli-tv-kd16:5.3.1.eng: And he should be put in charge like this.

pli-tv-kd16:5.3.2.pli: Paṭhamaṃ bhikkhu yācitabbo, yācitvā byattena bhikkhunā paṭibalena saṅgho ñāpetabbo—
pli-tv-kd16:5.3.2.eng: First a monk should be asked, and then a competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:

pli-tv-kd16:5.3.3.eng: ‘Please, venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.

pli-tv-kd16:5.3.4.pli: Yadi saṅghassa pattakallaṃ, saṅgho itthannāmassa gahapatino vihāraṃ itthannāmassa bhikkhuno navakammaṃ dadeyya.
pli-tv-kd16:5.3.4.eng: If the Sangha is ready, it should put monk so-and-so in charge of the building work relating to the dwelling of householder so-and-so.
pli-tv-kd16:5.3.4.comm: My rendering “should put (…) in charge” is for the Pali word dadeyya, which literally means, “Should give (out)”. Vmv 4.309: Dadeyyāti navakammaṁ adhiṭṭhātuṁ vihāre issariyaṁ dadeyyāti attho, “The meaning of dadeyya is that they should give control over the dwelling to supervise the building work.” This definition seems required by the context. The expression “the dwelling of householder so-and-so” can only be understood to mean a dwelling to be built for the Sangha by householder so-and-so.

pli-tv-kd16:5.3.6.eng: Please, venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.

pli-tv-kd16:5.3.7.pli: Saṅgho itthannāmassa gahapatino vihāraṃ itthannāmassa bhikkhuno navakammaṃ deti.
pli-tv-kd16:5.3.7.eng: The Sangha puts monk so-and-so in charge of the building work relating to the dwelling of householder so-and-so.

pli-tv-kd16:5.3.8.pli: Yassāyasmato khamati itthannāmassa gahapatino vihāraṃ itthannāmassa bhikkhuno navakammassa dānaṃ, so tuṇhassa;
pli-tv-kd16:5.3.8.eng: Any monk who approves of putting monk so-and-so in charge of the building work relating to the dwelling of householder so-and-so should remain silent.

pli-tv-kd16:5.3.9.eng: Any monk who doesn’t approve should speak up.

pli-tv-kd16:5.3.10.pli: Dinno saṅghena itthannāmassa gahapatino vihāro itthannāmassa bhikkhuno navakammaṃ.
pli-tv-kd16:5.3.10.eng: The Sangha has put monk so-and-so in charge of the building work relating to the dwelling of householder so-and-so.

pli-tv-kd16:5.3.11.pli: Khamati saṅghassa, tasmā tuṇhī, evametaṃ dhārayāmī’”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:5.3.11.eng: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I’ll remember it thus.’”

pli-tv-kd16:6.1.0.eng: 11. The instruction on the best seat, etc.

pli-tv-kd16:6.1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā vesāliyaṃ yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā yena sāvatthi tena cārikaṃ pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd16:6.1.1.eng: When the Buddha had stayed at Vesālī for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Sāvatthī.

pli-tv-kd16:6.1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ antevāsikā bhikkhū buddhappamukhassa saṅghassa purato purato gantvā vihāre pariggaṇhanti, seyyāyo pariggaṇhanti—
pli-tv-kd16:6.1.2.eng: On that occasion the monks who were the pupils of the monks from the group of six went ahead of the Sangha headed by the Buddha. They then took possession of dwellings and beds, thinking,

pli-tv-kd16:6.1.3.pli: “idaṃ amhākaṃ upajjhāyānaṃ bhavissati, idaṃ amhākaṃ ācariyānaṃ bhavissati, idaṃ amhākaṃ bhavissatī”ti.
pli-tv-kd16:6.1.3.eng: “This will be for our preceptors and teachers, and also for ourselves.”

pli-tv-kd16:6.1.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto buddhappamukhassa saṅghassa piṭṭhito piṭṭhito gantvā vihāresu pariggahitesu, seyyāsu pariggahitāsu, seyyaṃ alabhamāno aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd16:6.1.4.eng: Following behind the Sangha, Venerable Sāriputta was unable to get a bed—the dwellings and beds having all been taken. And so he sat down at the foot of a tree.

pli-tv-kd16:6.1.5.pli: Atha kho bhagavā rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ paccuṭṭhāya ukkāsi.
pli-tv-kd16:6.1.5.eng: Getting up early in the morning, the Buddha cleared his throat.

pli-tv-kd16:6.1.10.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesi.
pli-tv-kd16:6.1.10.eng: Sāriputta told the Buddha what had happened.

pli-tv-kd16:6.2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etasmiṃ nidāne etasmiṃ pakaraṇe bhikkhusaṅghaṃ sannipātāpetvā bhikkhū paṭipucchi—
pli-tv-kd16:6.2.1.eng: Soon afterwards the Buddha had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:

pli-tv-kd16:6.2.2.pli: “saccaṃ kira, bhikkhave, chabbaggiyānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ antevāsikā bhikkhū buddhappamukhassa saṅghassa purato purato gantvā vihāre pariggaṇhanti, seyyāyo pariggaṇhanti—
pli-tv-kd16:6.2.2.eng: “Is it true, monks, that the monks who are the pupils of the monks from the group of six did this?”

pli-tv-kd16:6.2.3.pli: idaṃ amhākaṃ upajjhāyānaṃ bhavissati, idaṃ amhākaṃ ācariyānaṃ bhavissati, idaṃ amhākaṃ bhavissatī”ti?

pli-tv-kd16:6.2.6.pli: kathañhi nāma te, bhikkhave, moghapurisā buddhappamukhassa saṅghassa purato purato gantvā vihāre pariggahessanti, seyyāyo pariggahessanti—

pli-tv-kd16:6.2.7.pli: idaṃ amhākaṃ upajjhāyānaṃ bhavissati, idaṃ amhākaṃ ācariyānaṃ bhavissati, idaṃ amhākaṃ bhavissatīti.
